awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Empowering faculty to run online learning experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Program: Education and Human Resources (IUSE: EHR), this project aims to serve the national interest by creating and improving open educational content in mathematics that resides on an open data-driven educational technology platform. The project will empower faculty to design and implement online learning experiments to test the effectiveness of new content and innovative teaching strategies. The data on how students use and learn from these materials will help instructors make effective use of the material in the classroom and enable authors to develop engaging educational experiences to maximize learning. Using this platform, instructors will be able to readily modify their materials in line with rapidly changing STEM fields and to adapt those materials to students' needs.

The project will develop the Distributed Open Education Network (Doenet), which is, at its core, a mechanism for measuring and sharing student interactions with web pages and storing anonymized data in an open distributed data warehouse. The Doenet platform will include tools for (a) authoring interactive educational content, (b) conducting educational research using the content, and (c) discovering the most effective content based on the research results. Doenet will reduce barriers to the development and access of online content and learning experiments. Faculty and researchers from a variety of institutions will employ Doenet to develop open interactive educational content and conduct small scale learning experiments, including experiments to investigate the influence of different ways of guiding students through the interactive content. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. This project falls in the program's Engaged Student Learning track, which enables the creation, exploration, and implementation of promising practices and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Doenet project (Distributed Open Education Network) empowers educators to design and implement content, and analyze learning experiments using interactive educational tools. Most notably, we produced a platform for deploying interactive math activities and built a community of educators using the platform. Key outcomes include technical advancements, the community, and contributions to educational research.


Doenet offers a cutting-edge platform that enables educators to create interactive online content and track student interactions. At its core is DoenetML, a powerful yet accessible declarative language that allows educators to design interactive problems and activities without needing extensive programming skills. Doenet offers many features, such as immediate feedback, randomized problem variations, and visual tools.


We collaborate with projects like PreTeXt and platforms like Runestone, integrating Doenet’s interactive capabilities into other STEM education tools. Additionally, Doenet’s open-source library of curated problems serves as a valuable resource for educators, allowing them to implement interactive content in their classrooms.


Our project also contributes to educational research, such as through collaborations with student projects, where machine learning models are used to predict student performance. These research efforts explore new metrics for evaluating student success, providing insights that inform teaching strategies and improve educational outcomes.


By aligning with the open educational resources (OER) movement, Doenet democratizes access to high-quality learning materials, particularly benefiting learners with limited resources. Its ability to collect and analyze anonymized student data allows educators to conduct experiments and improve teaching practices based on evidence. Approximately twenty colleges and universities have already adopted Doenet. Through workshops and presentations, we train educators in using Doenet, fostering a community committed to data-driven education.
